case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. M/s A. Raman Company

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 768 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 768 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 18, 1964 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 332 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated December 18, 1964 of the Gujarat High Court in Special Civil Application No. 332 of 1964.

facts.text: Assessees M/s A. Raman Company are dealers in mill stores.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees--M s A. Raman Company-are dealers in mill stores in the companyrse of their business they sell mill stores to other dealers

facts.text: Assessees sell mill stores to M/s A. M. Shah Co. and M/s R. Ambalal Co.

anchor.surface_text: in the companyrse of their business they sell mill stores to other dealers including two companycerns trading in the names of M s A. M. Shah Co. and M s R. Ambalal Co.

facts.text: M/s A. M. Shah Co. and M/s R. Ambalal Co. are owned by Hindu undivided families, managers of which are the only partners of the assessees.

anchor.surface_text: , which are owned by the Hindu undivided families, managers of which are the only partners of the assessees.

facts.text: Assessees were originally assessed for 1959-60, 1960-61, 1961-62 by Income-tax Officer, Circle-1, Ward-A, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1959-60, 1960-61 and 1961-62 the assessees were originally assessed by the Income-tax Officer, Circle-1, Ward-A, Ahmedabad,

facts.text: Partners of assessees and the two HUFs were assessed by Income-tax Officers in other Circles.

anchor.surface_text: while the partners of the assessees and the Hindu undivided families which traded in the names of M s A. M. Shah Co. and M s R. Ambalal Co. were assessed by Income-tax Officers in other Circles.

facts.text: Cases of assessees, partners, and two HUFs were transferred to Income-tax Officer, Group Circle-J, Ahmedabad.

anchor.surface_text: The cases of assessees, of the partners of the assessees and of the two Hindu undivided families trading in the names of M. Shah Co. and R. Ambalal Co. were later transferred to the Income-tax Officer, Group Circle-J, Ahmedabad.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer, Group Circle-J, Ahmedabad by letter dated March 20, 1964 informed assessees of conviction that partners diverted profits to HUFs to evade tax and called for objections to reopening assessments for 1959-60, 1960-61, 1961-62.

anchor.surface_text: That Officer by letter dated March 20, 1964 informed the assessees that he was companyvinced from a perusal of the assessment records of the assessees, their partners and their individual Hindu undivided families, that the partners of the assessees had companytrived to divert profits of the assessees to their respective Hindu undivided families and had tried to evade proper taxation, and on that ground he called upon the assessees to submit their objections, if any, to the reopening of the assessments for the years 1959- 60, 1960-61 and 1961-62.

facts.text: Assessees contended that Income-tax Officer had no jurisdiction to reopen assessments as they and HUFs submitted complete returns supported by books, details, and all material facts.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees in reply companytended that the Income-tax Officer had numberjurisdiction to reopen the assessments since the Hindu undivided families of the two partners and the assessees had submitted effect and companylete returns of income supported by their books of account, quantity details of purchases, sales and expenses, and had given all material facts and relevant information necessary for assessment at the time of each assessment.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued three separate notices under s. 147 of the Income-tax Act, 1961 for 1959-60, 1960-61, 1961-62.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer issued three separate numberices under s. 147 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, requiring the assessees to show cause why the assessments for the years 1959-60, 1960-61 and 1961-62 should number be reopened.

facts.text: Gujarat High Court quashed the notices and restrained ITO from proceeding in Special Civil Application No. 332 of 1964 under Art. 226.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Gujarat in a petition for a, writ under Art. 226 of the Constitution quashed those numberices and restrained the Income-tax Officer from taking proceedings in pursuance thereof.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave; Commissioner of Income-tax appealed.

anchor.surface_text: With special leave granted by this Court, the Commissioner of Income-tax has appealed to this Court.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer believed partners contrived to divert profits of assessees to their HUFs to evade taxation.

anchor.surface_text: ...that he was companyvinced from a perusal of the assessment records of the assessees, their partners and their individual Hindu undivided families, that the partners of the assessees had companytrived to divert profits of the assessees to their respective Hindu undivided families and had tried to evade proper taxation...

facts.text: Supreme Court held that Income-tax Officer had no reason to believe that income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that on the materials on the record, the Income-tax Officer. had numberreason to believe that income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment for the three years in question.

facts.text: High Court order quashing notices is confirmed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the High Court is therefore companyfirmed.

facts.text: Assessees effected sales to the said Hindu undivided families in earlier years.

anchor.surface_text: In the companyrse of the discussions I had at the several meetings hereinabove referred, I also learnt that in the earlier years also the petitioners  the assessees  had effected such sales to the said Hindu undivided families,

facts.text: Hindu undivided families earned substantial profits on resale of goods purchased from assessees.

anchor.surface_text: and that over and above the margin of profits earned by the petitioners  the assessees  from the Hindu undivided families, the Hindu undivided families had earned substantial profits on the resale of such goods.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer concluded that creation of HUF business was a subterfuge to divert profits.

anchor.surface_text: It was held by this Court in Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer... that the High Court in appropriate cases has power to issue an order prohibiting the Income-tax Officer from proceeding to reassess the income when the conditions precedent do not exist.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 147 1 b reason to believe that income chargeable to tax has escaped assessment in consequence of information in the possession of the Income-tax Officer is a condition precedent to the exercise of his jurisdiction to assess or reassess the income of the assessee.

holdings.text: High Court under Art. 226 has power to set aside notice under s.147 if condition precedent does not exist.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limits of judicial review; prima facie review only, not merits.

holdings.text: Information must come into ITO's possession after previous assessment, but jurisdiction not affected if it could have been obtained earlier but was not.

anchor.surface_text: That information, must, it is true, have come into the possession of the Income-tax Officer after the previous assessment, but even if the information be such that it could have been obtained during the previous assessment from an investigation of the materials on the record, or the facts disclosed thereby or from other enquiry or research into facts or law, but was not in fact obtained, the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer is not affected.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory purpose; actual possession matters, not potential availability.

holdings.text: On the materials, ITO had no reason to believe income chargeable to tax escaped assessment; no benami case, sales genuine, no obligation to maximize profits, avoidance legitimate.

anchor.surface_text: We hold, therefore, that on the materials on the record, the Income-tax Officer had no reason to believe that income chargeable to tax had escaped assessment for the three years in question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No diversion or sham; applies doctrines of no max profit duty, legitimate avoidance; rejects subterfuge inference.

holdings.text: Law does not oblige trader to make maximum profit; unearned potential income not taxable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle supporting no escape of assessee's income.

holdings.text: Avoidance of tax by arranging commercial affairs to distribute charge not prohibited; may lawfully circumvent statutes.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes evasion; effectiveness by Act's operation, not morality.

Income-tax Officer, Companies District I, Calcutta Another 1 that the High Court in appropriate cases has power to issue an order prohibiting the Income-tax Officer from proceeding to reassess the income when the conditions precedent do not exist. At p. 207, K. C. Das Gupta, J., delivering the majority judgment of the Court observed It is well-settled however that though the writ of prohibition or certiorari will not issue against an executive authority,

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Companies District I, Calcutta and Another
precedents.cited_proposition: High Court in appropriate cases has power to issue an order prohibiting the Income-tax Officer from proceeding to reassess the income when the conditions precedent do not exist; High Courts have power to issue writ prohibiting executive authority acting without jurisdiction where it subjects person to harassment
precedents.cited_holding: It is well-settled however that though the writ of prohibition or certiorari will not issue against an executive authority, the High Courts have power to issue in a fit case an order prohibiting an executive authority from acting without jurisdiction. Where such action of an executive authority acting without jurisdiction subjects or is likely to subject a person to lengthy proceedings and unnecessary harassment, the High Courts... will issue appropriate orders...

anchor.surface_text: The order passed by the High Court is therefore companyfirmed.

outcome.relief_summary: The order passed by the High Court is therefore confirmed

anchor.surface_text: The High Court exercising jurisdiction under Art. 226 of the Constitution has power to set aside a notice issued under s. 147 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, if the condition precedent to the exercise of the jurisdiction does not exist.
The order passed by the High Court is therefore companyfirmed.

anchor.surface_text: That information, must, it is true, have come into the possession of the Income-tax Officer after the previous assessment, but even if the information be such that it could have been obtained during the previous assessment from an investigation of the materials on the record, or the facts disclosed thereby or from other enquiry or research into facts or law, but was not in fact obtained, the jurisdiction of the Income-tax Officer is not affected.
The order passed by the High Court is therefore companyfirmed.
